title: IRC Archive for channel #xwiki - XWiki
content:

09:00 <kwoot> goodmorning. tryign some new stuff. how can I change the max\_upload setting in xwiki 3.0?  
09:04 <pulasthi> has joined #xwiki  
09:07 <kwoot> found it.  
09:29 <sburjan> has joined #xwiki  
09:36 <tmortagne> has joined #xwiki  
09:42 <pulasthi> cjdelisle : hi what should i look into next :)  
09:48 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
09:50 <+sburjan> do we have some new rule on maven to keep only the last 2 builds ?  
09:54 <vmassol> sburjan: yes, this is done in nexus  
09:55 <vmassol> last 2 snapshot builds to be precise  
09:55 <vmassol> we never remove release builds  
09:55 <+sburjan> but I guess this is new.. I noticed it only yesterday  
09:55 <vmassol> no it's not new  
09:55 <vmassol> been like this for a few years  
09:55 <+sburjan> well usually there were all snaps on maven  
09:55 <vmassol> but we changed the rule slightly a few weeks ago  
09:55 <vmassol> nope  
09:56 <+sburjan> I am downloading snaps for one year now :)  
09:56 <+sburjan> and usually there were more than 2 ...  
09:56 <vmassol> not really but anyway it doesn't matter  
09:56 <vmassol> what's the issue?  
09:57 <vmassol> (is there one?)  
09:57 <+sburjan> none.. just keeping track on what happens on platform  
09:57 <vmassol> ok good  
09:58 <vmassol> I've just checked the current rule  
09:58 <vmassol> it's set to keep 1 snapshot minimum  
09:58 <vmassol> and the removal is done every 2 days  
09:58 <vmassol> I mean snapshots older than 2 days are removed  
09:58 <vmassol> (unless there's only 1 of course)  
09:59 <vmassol> and the check is done daily  
09:59 <+tmortagne> sburjan: it used to be 5 and is now 2  
09:59 <+sburjan> I see.  
09:59 <+sburjan> ok, now makes sense :)  
10:00 <vmassol> guys what's blocking the release?  
10:00 <vmassol> I don't recall if sergiu fixed the regression he introduced  
10:07 <vmassol> sburjan: what issues have you already reported for oracle? I can find XWIKI-6683. Any more?  
10:07 <vmassol> ah 6682 too  
10:07 <+sburjan> XWIKI-6683 might be related to AS indexing and to be independent of Oracle  
10:21 <abusenius> has joined #xwiki  
10:23 <+tmortagne> vmassol: XWIKI-6705 is an important regression right ?  
10:23 <vmassol> ym   
10:23 <vmassol> s/ym//  
10:23 <+tmortagne> I tough you wrote test for it  
10:24 <vmassol> tmortagne: have you confirmed it?  
10:24 <vmassol> yes I did  
10:24 <+tmortagne> not me  
10:24 <vmassol> which surprises me  
10:24 <vmassol> I'm in a meeting now  
10:24 <vmassol> so cannot check  
10:24 <+tmortagne> just seen it  
10:24 <vmassol> would be good if someone can check it out  
10:24 <+tmortagne> putting it as blocker until I can confirm or close it  
10:24 <vmassol> ok  
10:25 <Chami> has quit  
10:26 <+tmortagne> cjdelisle: XWIKI-6705 is a blocker, I'm trying to confirm it  
10:26 <+tmortagne> hope it's a false alarm  
10:35 <+tmortagne> cjdelisle, vmassol: looks like it's a false alert  
10:36 <vmassol> pfew  
10:36 <+tmortagne> yep

10:42 <abusenius> has quit  
10:53 <sdumitriu> has joined #xwiki  
11:00 <vmassol> has quit  
11:03 <pulasthi> has quit  
11:06 <vmassol> has joined #xwiki  
11:07 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
11:09 <+tmortagne> hmm jboss finally closed its old maven repository which make 3.0 build fail, trying to fix it  
11:11 <+tmortagne> we should release 3.0.1 ASAP and get rid of this branch  
11:12 <vmassol> tmortagne: yes, we need to know what we release for 3.0.1  
11:12 <vmassol> ie what version of apps/plugins we release  
11:12 <vmassol> (skins too)  
11:13 <vmassol> I started a filter on jira  
11:13 <vmassol> but I've not included apps/plugins/skins yet since I didn't know whihc one we want to release for 3.0.1  
11:13 <vmassol> http://jira.xwiki.org/jira/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?mode=hide&requestId=10940  
11:14 <evalica> has quit  
11:14 <+tmortagne> I think the one we need have been included in the platform repository by sdumitriu  
11:15 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
11:15 <+tmortagne> and the build modified to release them with the platform version like in 3.1 and 3.2  
11:16 <@sdumitriu> Yes  
11:16 <vmassol> sdumitriu: could you update the filter/release plan with that information?  
11:17 <cjdelisle> what's holding up the release at this point?  
11:17 <vmassol> sdumitriu: did you fix the issue for 3.1 release?  
11:18 <vmassol> (the regression caused by your change for migrating properties)  
11:18 <vmassol> (the failing tests)  
11:19 <@sdumitriu> Not yet  
11:22 <cjdelisle> XWIKI-6697  
11:23 <cjdelisle> It is not listed as a blocker, is it ok to revert the changes and release with it broken?  
11:26 <abusenius> has joined #xwiki  
11:27 <vmassol> guys is agent3 ok now?  
11:27 <@sdumitriu> cjdelisle: It is a blocker  
11:28 <vmassol> we don't seem to be running much on it: http://ci.xwiki.org/computer/agent-3/builds  
11:28 <vmassol> we need to know if it's ok  
11:28 <vmassol> because if it is then we can add more agents on that machine  
11:28 <vmassol> it looks ok to me  
11:29 <+tmortagne> yes looks  ok  
11:29 <vmassol> cjdelisle: could we allow tests to be executed on it ?  
11:29 <vmassol> I will report to alex so that we can more agents on the machine  
11:30 <cjdelisle> more agents is cool but I don't know how we can avoid resource collision  
11:31 <cjdelisle> Here's an idea...  
11:31 <cjdelisle> put 2 users on the box  
11:31 <cjdelisle> user1 has 1 agent (err I mean executor)  and user2 has 4.  
11:31 <cjdelisle> user1 and user2 are technically distinct agents  
11:31 <cjdelisle> that way user1 in box3 is allowed to run tests but user2 is not  
11:31 <vmassol> collision with what?  
11:32 <Enygma`> has quit  
11:32 <sburjan> has quit  
11:32 <cjdelisle> if you have 4 executors on box3 then what happens when they start running enterprise-tests and enterprise-tests-3.1 concurrently?  
11:33 <evalica> has quit  
11:33 <vmassol> they are in different VM  
11:33 <vmassol> they're completely isolated  
11:33 <vmassol> the only contention is the artifact upload  
11:33 <cjdelisle> ok you're thinking of something differenrt then  
11:34 <cjdelisle> I was thinking about that little box in jenkins that says:  Number of executors [ 1 ]  
11:34 <vmassol> where is that?  
11:35 <cjdelisle> http://ci.xwiki.org/computer/agent-3/configure  
11:35 <cjdelisle> third field down from the top  
11:42 <vmassol> cjdelisle: ok. My take is that we don't need to change this field value FTM since we can have isolated VMs  
11:42 <cjdelisle> vms will be more complete in their isolation but using multiple executors will be easier on ram.  
11:44 <cjdelisle> abusenius: I found a neat trick for securing a linux program, if you know what files you will need to open beforehand, you can open them when it starts then ste your file descriptor limit to 0.  
11:45 <cjdelisle> Wrote a test for it and it works: http://pastebay.com/126086  you keep the handles you already have but as soon as you close them, they're done.  
11:45 <+abusenius> cjdelisle: nice, I wonder if it works the same on different \*n?x-es...  
11:46 <cjdelisle> not of IBM z/os, they won't let you decrease the limit below what you have open  
11:46 <cjdelisle> but it's a cool trick for the 90% of the users who are running plain old linux  
11:48 <cjdelisle> no files --> no fork() no sockets, I don't think you can even execute another program since it would fail when it tried to give you stdin  
11:56 <vmassol> xwiki.org is running 2.6.2, should we upgrade it to 3.0.1 when it's out?  
12:00 <+tmortagne> +1  
12:00 <+tmortagne> if not even 3.1  
12:01 <evalica1> has joined #xwiki  
12:03 <vmassol> tmortagne: I'd like autowatch for import fixed before installing it  
12:04 <+tmortagne> vmassol: what do you mean fixed ? I already committed a quick fix based on import log for it as I told you  
12:04 <vmassol> ok had forgotten this one  
12:04 <vmassol> in any case for xwiki.org I prefer to instlal stable versions  
12:04 <vmassol> by stable I mean dot releases  
12:04 <vmassol> 3.1.1  
12:05 <vmassol> we alreayd have a test platform for myxwki so we don't need to have the latest on xwiki.org  
12:05 <vmassol> anyway we need to upgrade xwiki.org....  
12:05 <sburjan> has joined #xwiki  
12:10 <Enygma`> has joined #xwiki  
12:11 <@sdumitriu> Fixing XWIKI-6697  
12:15 <abusenius> has quit  
12:27 <@sdumitriu> cjdelisle: Done with the regression  
12:28 <@sdumitriu> You can start the release (or wait for the tests to run)  
12:30 <cjdelisle> thanks  
12:58 <Chami> has joined #xwiki  
13:01 <cjdelisle> So does adding tags with html work?  
13:06 <abusenius> has joined #xwiki  
13:16 <evalica1> has quit  
13:24 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
13:31 <evalica> has quit  
13:32 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
13:34 <Enygma`> has quit  
13:44 <vmassol> hmm anyone knows why this page has only 1 version and i can still see the spam comment: http://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Blog/XWiki+is+participating+in+Google+Summer+of+Code+2011#History ?  
13:45 <cjdelisle> did you add a tag to hallOfFame?  
13:46 <vmassol> cjdelisle: me? no  
13:46 <cjdelisle> scroll up  
13:46 <vmassol> I did'nt  
13:46 <vmassol> it's smebs123  
13:46 <vmassol> it's been rolledback already  
13:46 <cjdelisle> this xwikibot is getting annoying  
13:46 <@sdumitriu> By me  
13:47 <vmassol> sdumitriu: but on http://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Blog/XWiki+is+participating+in+Google+Summer+of+Code+2011#History there's something werid  
13:47 <vmassol> weird  
13:47 <@sdumitriu> What?  
13:48 <vmassol> "hmm anyone knows why this page has only 1 version and i can still see the spam comment:"  
13:48 <@sdumitriu> Cache?  
13:48 <vmassol> maybe but that's still an issue  
13:48 <@sdumitriu> Yes  
13:49 <vmassol> so how do we refresh the caceh selectively?  
13:49 <vmassol> edit the page maybe?  
13:49 <vmassol> but then it's going to change the RSS feeds for users...  
13:49 <vmassol> ok I'll just try to delete the comment  
13:52 <@sdumitriu> Or maybe it's http://jira.xwiki.org/jira/browse/XWIKI-3366  
13:54 <vmassol> hmm I don't recall seeing this issue before, sounds like an important issue  
13:55 <@sdumitriu> It's marked Critical  
13:55 <@sdumitriu> But with no plan to fix it so far  
13:58 <fmancinelli> has joined #xwiki  
14:07 <Enygma`> has joined #xwiki  
14:45 <sburjan> has quit  
14:45 <sburjan> has joined #xwiki  
14:46 <DrLou> has joined #xwiki  
14:53 <evalica1> has joined #xwiki  
14:55 <evalica> has quit  
14:55 <abusenius> has quit  
14:55 <sburjan> has quit  
14:57 <Enygma`> has quit  
15:09 <sburjan> has joined #xwiki  
15:11 <Enygma`> has joined #xwiki  
15:17 <vmassol> tmortagne: shouldn't we turn autowatch off by default for the 3.1 release?  
15:17 <vmassol> cjdelisle: when are you starting the release?  
15:18 <cjdelisle> I was hoping to see this complete  
15:18 <cjdelisle> http://ci.xwiki.org/job/xwiki-enterprise-tests-3.1/134/  
15:18 <cjdelisle> but that might be a lot to expect  
15:19 <vmassol> ouch those 2 failing tests are not good: http://ci.xwiki.org/job/xwiki-enterprise-tests-3.1/org.xwiki.enterprise$xwiki-enterprise-test-ui/134/testReport/  
15:19 <vmassol> I don't recall them failing before  
15:19 <cjdelisle> yes, just noticed this  
15:19 <vmassol> sdumitriu: could they still be caused by your changes?  
15:19 <cjdelisle> you type faster than me :P  
15:19 <vmassol> ;)  
15:27 <+tmortagne> vmassol: maybe for 3.1 specifically yes but should definitely be kept as default for 3.2  
15:28 <vmassol> I'm not sure about the "definitely"  
15:28 <vmassol> let's focus on 3.1 for now  
15:28 <vmassol> wdyt guys?  
15:28 <+tmortagne> if not it's pretty useless since nobody will either know about it  
15:29 <vmassol> IMO this needs to be discussed, it's not "obvious", at least for me  
15:30 <+tmortagne> vmassol: this has been voted it's not a decision I made alone  
15:31 <vmassol> ok I didn' tremember. Let me re-read that thread. I'll send another vote mail then if I still don't agree after reading that thread  
15:32 <+Denis> are you talking about the watch list being filled automatically ?  
15:33 <vmassol> here's my use case Deis  
15:33 <vmassol> Denis  
15:33 <vmassol> I edit a page  
15:33 <vmassol> this page gets added to my watchlist automaitcally  
15:33 <vmassol> then I receive email from the watchlist later on  
15:33 <vmassol> even if I have never said I wanted to receive emails nor that I want the autowatch feature  
15:34 <vmassol> IMO there are other solution to make it auto discoverable  
15:37 <+Denis> I think the idea is good to have default that activate feature, and I do not consider email an issue if the email clearly state how to get rid of them, but we have face a severe issue due to this new feature:  
15:37 <+Denis> the global admin has started to watch thousand of documents imported or automatically generated, and after a while, the document stop saving properly, generating logs.  
15:38 <vmassol> bbiab  
15:38 <+Denis> I notice that each watch has caused the admin user document to have a new revision history, also, and it was a pain to get rid of all that stuff (I had to recreate the global admin in hurry)  
15:39 <+Denis> so I now clearly advice that admin user should not have such feature activated by default  
15:39 <+Denis> this my story on how I have discovered the feature !  
15:40 <+Denis> :)  
15:44 <+tmortagne> Denis: I did a quickfix for import already  
15:46 <+Denis> tmortagne: it was not the import that have cause the issue mainly, but some groovy code that create bunch of documents… using the usual API. Is there a special way to save document from code and avoid the watchlist ?  
15:47 <+tmortagne> Denis: yes you can save document diretly using storage api instead of XWiki  
15:47 <+tmortagne> unless you still need events for other reasons  
15:47 <+Denis> sure but this require PR  
15:47 <cjdelisle> you can't opt out of watching a document when you save it?  
15:47 <+tmortagne> sure  
15:48 <+tmortagne> Denis: you can also simply disable autowatch  
15:48 <+tmortagne> you just need right to modify your profile for that  
15:48 <+Denis> yes, my point is about existing wiki and discovering the way we have discovered the new feature  
15:49 <cjdelisle> If it's on by default, I think more people are going to discover it in a bad way than people discover it in a good way.  
15:52 <abusenius> has joined #xwiki  
15:54 <+Denis> cjdelisle: maybe, it should be off, and setup on in the configuration file. A user migrating and keeping its old config will not be impacted, and the one who update its config should see the comment associated with the parameter in the config file ?  
15:55 <cjdelisle> I have not followed the development of that closely so I don't know much about it  
15:56 <+tmortagne> Denis: it is set in the configuration file  
15:57 <+Denis> I have not myself, but I imagine that there is parameter in the config and that we debate if it on or off by default  
15:57 <+tmortagne> by default user configuration is "default"  
15:57 <+tmortagne> which mean whatever is  in the configuration file  
15:57 <+Denis> but what is the default of the configuration file ?  
15:59 <+Denis> (when nothing is set in the configuration file itself)  
15:59 <+tmortagne> like most of the prooperty it's commented in the configuration file by default  
15:59 <+Denis> which means ?  
15:59 <+tmortagne> which means as you can see youself it's enbaled by default...  
15:59 <+tmortagne> enabled$  
15:59 <+Denis> this is probably the bad part of it, I suggest to be disabled, but to uncomment the config file to enable it  
15:59 <+tmortagne> otherwise there would not be this dicussion :)  
16:00 <+Denis> this way, only new wiki installation will be impacted  
16:00 <+tmortagne> I don't see the point  
16:00 <+tmortagne> there is no old installation with that  
16:00 <+tmortagne> it's a 3.1 feature  
16:00 <+Denis> yes but when you upgrade from earlier release, you generally keep your configuration  
16:01 <+Denis> or you at least review it  
16:01 <+tmortagne> so you want it to be disabled by defaul after an upgrade but enabled by default with a standard install ?  
16:02 <+Denis> so, when nothing is in the config file, if the result is a disable feature, but if the distribution contains the enabling line (not commented) in the config file, you will cover most common cases and expose the feature as well  
16:03 <+Denis> do you get the idea ?  
16:03 <+tmortagne> no really no  
16:03 <+tmortagne> I don't see what that change for new install  
16:04 <+tmortagne> you still have it enabled by default  
16:04 <+tmortagne> so you have the exact same bahavior  
16:04 <+tmortagne> behavior  
16:04 <+Denis> yes, exposing feature is good IMHO  
16:04 <+Denis> but adding feature that could be dicovered badly on upgrade is bad  
16:05 <+Denis> so I see 3 cases:  
16:05 <+tmortagne> so that' what I said "so you want it to be disabled by defaul after an upgrade but enabled by default with a standard install"  
16:05 <+Denis> 1) I am a new user, I just use the default config, and I get all the features  
16:06 <+Denis> 2) I am an upgrading user, I keep my config files, and do not get the feature  
16:06 <+Denis> 3) I am an upgrading user, I review the new config file, discover there is a new feature enabled, and decide or not to keep it  
16:07 <+tmortagne> I understand your point of view but I don't like too much counting that much on configuration file  
16:08 <+tmortagne> IMO in a default install everything should be commented as much as possible  
16:08 <+Denis> not sure this a common principal  
16:09 <+Denis> principle  
16:09 <+tmortagne> it's not like we were talking about something that would make en upgrade impossible  
16:10 <+Denis> my talk is general, new install should espose as much as possible new feature, but upgrading user should decide for themself on a voluntary basis, if these feature should be enabled  
16:11 <+Denis> else, they could discover these feature in a bad way  
16:14 <j-saturne> has joined #xwiki  
16:16 <j-saturne> has quit  
16:16 <j-saturne> has joined #xwiki  
16:27 <cjdelisle> sdumitriu: Are we all set to release?  
16:33 <abusenius> has quit  
16:38 <+sburjan> I think I found a major or a blocker  
16:38 <+sburjan> it seems the rename function does not work as normal user  
16:38 <+sburjan> rename page  
16:40 <+sburjan> yepp, doesn't work. Tested on FF and Chrome  
16:42 <+sburjan> XWIKI-6708  
16:44 <cjdelisle> is there a stack trace?  
16:45 <+sburjan> no stacktrace. nor in the page, nor in the console  
16:45 <+sburjan> testing on : http://maven.xwiki.org/snapshots/org/xwiki/enterprise/xwiki-enterprise-jetty-hsqldb/3.1-SNAPSHOT/xwiki-enterprise-jetty-hsqldb-3.1-20110614.154018-216.zip  
16:46 <+sburjan> don't we have automated tests for page rename ?  
16:47 <cjdelisle> #  SIGILL (0x4) at pc=0x00007faa43b4c713, pid=6986, tid=140369260263136  
16:47 <cjdelisle> # An error report file with more information is saved as:  
16:47 <cjdelisle> Segmentation fault  
16:48 <cjdelisle> heh  
16:49 <+sburjan> got that too once  
16:50 <cjdelisle> I sent the sigkill but it handled it less than gracefully  
16:52 <+sburjan> could you confirm ? I think should be listed as Blocker if you confirm it  
16:53 <cjdelisle> my wiki is in pieces right now, one piece is sitting on the desk and the other is on the floor and I'm trying to see if I can patch cassandra into it  
16:54 <cjdelisle> I don't think you should need 2 people to repeat it in order to know it's real, go ahead and mark it blocker if you think it is.  
16:59 <+sburjan> IMO it is  
17:10 <+sburjan> done.. it's a blocker  
17:17 <@sdumitriu> sburjan: That's always been the case, IIRC  
17:17 <@sdumitriu> Rename requires delete  
17:17 <@sdumitriu> And delete requires either admin, or to be the creator of the documenbt  
17:18 <@sdumitriu> You can try to rename a new page that you created, that should work  
17:18 <@sdumitriu> About autowatch: I also strongly feel that the feature should be disabled by default  
17:18 <+sburjan> well... I create my document. For example Main.WebHome cannot be renamed as a regular user. But when a regular user creates a page, he should be the creator  
17:18 <@sdumitriu> Mediawiki/wikipedia has "Watch this page" unchecked initially  
17:18 <+sburjan> sdumitriu: exactly, it doesn't work. I can't rename a page I created

18:24 <fmancinelli> [git] I am using a fork for doing my developments and I periodically fetch/merge upstream/master. This has the side effect of a lot of commits "Merge remote-tracking branch 'upstream/master'" next to the ones on real features... How do you handle this?  
18:26 <@sdumitriu> fmancinelli: Those are not that bad  
18:26 <@sdumitriu> Depends what you want to do with the branch  
18:27 <@sdumitriu> They can be safely ignore  
18:27 <@sdumitriu> d  
18:28 <cjdelisle> if your changes will be pulled later then you could branch your fork repo and squash all of your revisions together then have one (or a few) commits to pull request  
18:28 <+Denis> fmancinelli: If you do your development on separate branch (which is highly recommanded), you may follow up on master and the branches you want/need from upstream, simply by fast-forwarding them  
18:29 <fmancinelli> Well I usually do this: merge upstream, create a branch for feature X from my fork/master, develop X, checkout master, merge feature X, delete branch X, merge upstream, push to my fork, send pull request on  
18:29 <fmancinelli> \*send pull request to upstream  
18:30 <+Denis> I would not merge anything to master, and just keep it untouched  
18:31 <cjdelisle> good point there  
18:33 <fmancinelli> denis: you mean keep the branch X and issue the pull request directly from that branch, right?  
18:39 <+Denis> yes  
18:41 <+Denis> but more, I would suggest that you never merge to master change from upstream, but simply fast-forward it  
18:41 <@sdumitriu> Sometimes ff doesn't work  
18:42 <+Denis> why, if you keep master untouched, it should always  
18:51 <fmancinelli> has quit  
18:53 <+jvelociter> fast-forward == rebase ?  
18:54 <+jvelociter> or its something different ?  
18:55 <+Denis> jvelociter: no, fast-forward is when a branch is backward, and is simply updated by moving forward to the last commit  
18:56 <+jvelociter> ok  
18:58 <+Denis> I be back in a moment, I could resume how I setup and maintain a fork if you want
